thread.title_full: Fitbit defends step goal after experts criticise 10,000 a day target as meaningless

author: James Titcomb
title: Fitbit defends step goal after experts criticise 10,000 a day target as meaningless

organizations.name: american association for the advancement of science

text:
F itbit has defended its 10,000 steps a day goal after scientists said there was no evidence for the target.
The world’s biggest maker of fitness trackers puts a 10,000 step goal as the default on every fitness tracker it sells, a figure that was criticised this week for having little evidence to support it.
A Fitbit spokesman pointed to advice on the company's website saying the goal equates to around five miles , which helps towards American health guidelines of 150 minutes of moderate exercise a week. Fitbit also points to a 2010 study showing "conclusive health benefits" of walking 10,000 steps a day.
However, the company said the goal was not a “one-size-fits-all” option, and said users could adjust their step count.
The five most ridiculous fitness trends ever S ome other fitness trackers, including the Apple Watch , use different measurements, such as higher-intensity exercise, but Fitbit continues to use steps as the main target.
“Fitbit’s mission to help people lead healthier, more active lives by empowering them with data, inspiration, and guidance to reach their goals,” a spokesman said.
“We understand that there is no ‘one size fits all’ option in fitness, so our users are able to customize all of their health and fitness goals, including steps.”
Fitbit is the world's biggest fitness tracker maker Credit: Bloomberg I t comes after experts said many apps and fitness devices have no real evidence base, and that the 10,000 steps a day goal was based on a small study of Japanese men dating back to 1960.
“Some of you might wear Fitbits or something equivalent, and I bet every now and then it gives you that cool little message 'you did 10,000 steps today’,” Dr Greg Hager, an expert in computer science at Johns Hopkins University, told delegates at the American Association for the Advancement of Science annual meeting in Boston.
Athletes create amazing GPS map art with fitness trackers: in pictures “But why is 10,000 steps important? Is that the right number for any of you in this room? Who knows? It’s just a number that’s now built into the apps.”
F itbit reported a 19 per cent fall in revenue this week after selling 6.5 million devices in the final quarter of last year, down from 8.2 million a year ago.
